fields.description:
Just noticed that several RSS feeds we have in Crucible (e.g. Custom Review Search) include all matching reviews in the results.  This may result in several thousands of reviews to be built, it takes time and resources to build that and potentially degrade overall Crucible performance.
Typical RSS clients reads RSS on a scheduled basis which means on popular instances there might be several feeds being built at any given moment.
Usually RSS are meant to bring just the recent results, we should truncate results to the 10 or couple dozens at most recent results.
Note this feature might be potentially used as export tool to import review data into other data sources, e.g. Excel, see CRUC-6437.  Perhaps we want to offer better way of exporting data before we tackle this issue.
fields.summary: RSS feeds from Crucible review searches do not truncate results

fields.description:
This support case https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-15382 might be caused by using timed out idle connections. See also http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9202813/oracle-thin-jdbc-connection-receiving-connection-reset-after-inactivity for this sort of problem.

We have default DB pool values:

        cfg.setProperty(BONECP_IDLE_MAX_AGE, "0"); //we don't want idle connections timing out
        cfg.setProperty(BONECP_IDLE_CONNECTION_TEST_PERIOD, "60"); //we do want idle connections to be kept alive by pings

The reviewers of this change were under the impression that the test period units were seconds, but they are actually minutes: https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/cru/CR-FE-6758#c72732

I propose that we change the max age to 10 minutes and the test period to 2 minutes.

Thoughts [~pswiecicki], [~cmacneill], [~npellow]?
fields.summary: Improvements to DB Pool Defaults

When a reviewers is perusing their reviews, they inspect the list of files in the left hand pane under Details, Objectives, etc.  They want a quick means of determining how large an inspection this particular review is.  There is the list of files but no idea of the amount of churn/diffs there are in each file. Files added(green) or deleted(red) show up in different colours but 10% of the population is colourblind.

Right now the number of comments is displayed to the right of each file.  Can you add a churn number in square brackets to the right of the files as well.  The churn number is the addition of the absolute values of lines added, deleted or modified

fields.description:
A diff from a local branch to trunk in the SVN server can be created with {{LANG=C svn diff --old https://svn/trunk --new . > myDiff.patch}}  (the "LANG=C" is to work around CRUC-6854). The resulting patch file is:

{noformat}
Index: path/to/some/file.c
===================================================================
--- path/to/some/file.c	(https://svn/trunk)	(revision 1234)
+++ path/to/some/file.c	(working copy)
{noformat}

And again Crucible fails to understand this due to the "{{(https://svn/trunk)}}" and cannot anchor the patch to any repository.
fields.summary: Support diff/path files with entries refering to different branches

fields.description:
I'm not sure if you would consider this a bug; probably an improvement. I'll open it as a bug and see how long it lasts.

We use both Crucible & Stash; some teams only use Crucible for code reviews and some teams use Stash pull requests for code reviews. The Stash teams have also started used some of the enhanced things like locking down develop or master and requiring pull requests to merge to them. 
The problem is the teams that use Crucible for code reviews are now doing the same thing - they create reviews via smart commits (+review), do their Crucible review, it gets approved, and then a pull request is used to merge their branch back into develop/master. Or a pull request is used to merge their commit to a release branch (think git flow here). Fisheye parses the commits and makes another review in Crucible when it encounters the +review again. 

So there's some aberrant behavior here in my opinion. 
1) Why is FeCru creating a new review when it sees the same commit hash go by again? Shouldn't it be smart enough to ignore the +review if it already processed that hash?
2) Or, can I have a checkbox/toggle in the Smart Commit configuration screen to not parse smart commits on merges? I realize some workflows may want them parsed on merges, but we do not, so it would nice if it were toggleable. A global toggle is fine. 

-Kelly G. Schoenhofen
fields.summary: Smart commits should ignore merges to avoid processing commits multiple times via pull requests

fields.description:
h3. Summary
A Git branch identical to the master (no new commits to the new branch or the master since branch creation), is not showed in the {{Browse Changesets}} option in Crucible when adding content to a review. 

h3. Environment
Git repository added to a Crucible instance.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Git repository with one or more branches, all identical to the master.
# Add the repository to Crucible.
# Create a review in Crucible and click on {{Browse Changesets}}.

h3. Expected Results
Crucible showing all the branches present in the Stash repository.

h3. Actual Results
Crucible shows only the master branch.

h3. Workaround #1

Perform a commit in each of the new branches; in this way they appear in the {{Browse Changesets}} option in Crucible when adding content to a review.

h3. Workaround #2

Install the attached  [^baserevisioncache-findbranches-use-lucene.btm] Byteman script ([how to install the script|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/enable-byteman-for-additional-logging-in-fisheye-and-crucible-943956769.html] ). It will use Lucene search index as an alternative data source to fetch all open branches. Note that it returns up to 1000 branches, you may want to change the limit in the script.
fields.summary: Branches created in Git repository don't appear in Crucible until a commit is made to it

fields.description:
h3. Original issue

The following error is thrown when we attempt to load a particular review (the entire stack trace is attached as well)...

{panel}

Your request was unable to be processed
javax.servlet.ServletException - javax.el.ELException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Comparison method violates its general contract!

    javax.el.ELException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Comparison method violates its general contract!
    java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Comparison method violates its general contract!
    Comparison method violates its general contract!

You are running release CR2.10.4 FE2.10.4 (20130403093648 2013-04-03), please report your release number when reporting bugs.
Got a problem or a suggestion?

Visit the support website for your support options.

{panel}

We saw [this KB article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Comparison+method+violates+its+general+contract] that states it's a bug in the JDK, BUT we think it's actually a bug in Fisheye/Crucible (See [this specific comment|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-36857?focusedCommentId=577178&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-577178] in [JRA-36857|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-36857]).

Please investigate this and let us know what we can do to resolve this. If you have any questions or need any further information, don't hesitate to ask.  Thanks in advance!

h3. Developer explanation

The bug was in an asymmetric comparator and was fixed in FeCru 3.1. (1bc8903).

h3. Fix

Upgrade to FishEye/Crucible 3.1+.

h3. Workaround

Add the following to your JVM parameters:
{noformat}
-Djava.util.Arrays.useLegacyMergeSort=true
{noformat}
fields.summary: "Comparison method violates its general contract!" Error is thrown when attempting to load a review

fields.description:
Currently, if command line interface tool "crucible.py" is used to add a patch to review and the "svn diff" contain only new files, the anchor will fail and the patch is not uploaded.

We will need to use the option "--noanchor" when uploading the patch with "crucible.py" so that it will not have the fail message:
{noformat}
Error: Failed to anchor the patch to repository subversion, please check that the repository is the correct one
{noformat}

The CLI tool "crucible.py" should detect new file from the diff and automatically disable anchoring to a repository so that it will not fail to upload the patch.

Also, if repository to anchor patch to was provided when uploading patch, perhaps Crucible should honour it and anchor the patch to that repository, as long as it contains new files only and none of those files already exist in selected repository?
fields.summary: Review CLI Tool should be able to upload a patch containing only added files

fields.description:
The REST API */rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?* isn't picking up the fromDate & toDate parameters. 

For example when submitting the below URL;
 
_/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?project=GP&states=Closed_

All closed reviews are shown as expected, however when adding an extreme fromDate parameter with a value such as =8910096081 (_Sat, 08 May 2252 02:41:21 GMT_) all the closed reviews still show.

Also when the toDate parameter is included no results are returned.

So for the URL _/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?
project=GP&states=Closed&fromDate=1410096081&toDate=1411464440_ no results are returned whereas if the toDate param is removed all closed reviews are shown.
fields.summary: REST API toDate & fromDate parameters aren't enforced
Poor performance on review creation with large changeset

fields.description:
h3. Summary
FishEye lists a file even if its last change occurred prior to the +Start Revision+ set for the repository, but it fails anchoring a patch to it with the following message: 
{noformat} 
No repository found to anchor patch to 
Crucible tried to anchor your patch to 'patch3', but did not find any matching revisions. You will not be able to do iterative reviews on this patch. 
{noformat} 
!patch.png|thumbnail! 

Nothing is shown in the logs and, as the file actually appears as listed, it is not clear why the patch is not anchored. 

h3.Test Scenario 
* *File changed*: readme 
* *Latest revision for the file in the repository*: 33 
* *Start revision in Crucible*: 36 
* *Repository's current revision*: 96 

h3.Steps to Reproduce 
# Apply any change to the file *readme* in the repository. 
# Create a patch: 
{noformat} 
svn diff > patch.txt 
{noformat} 
# Try attaching the patch. The "No repository found" message will show up. 

h3. Notes
The Git and Mercurial related use case is described in the [CRUC-7523|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-7523] ticket.

h3.Workaround 
# When generating the patch, specify the current revision: 
{noformat} 
svn diff -r96 > patch.txt 
{noformat} 
# Try attaching the patch. It will be succesfully attached, containing the changes not commited yet against the latest revision of the repository.
fields.summary: Trying to anchor a patch for a file with no indexed revisions fails

fields.description:
When creating a Crucible review using the pre-commit method of attaching (or cut&paste) a diff/patch file, Crucible anchors it to the wrong branch by default but indicates that it was "successfully" anchored to the repository.

In this case, the designer had checked out from the SVN based 'AP' repository on /main branch.  Changes were made and 'svn diff' of the local workspace created a patch file.   The entire patch file was uploaded resulted in an error message indicating a file was in conflict with "branches/reviews/15B/capwap_lbol" branch.  This is another designer's private branch but he is working on the same files.

If I cut&paste individual file diffs then the patch indicates that it was "successfully" anchored but to this wrong branch: branches/reviews/15B/capwap_lbol.  See the attached jpg image.

I can manually edit the branch and tell it to use /main but some of the files get anchored and some do not.

I need a viable solution when using this pre-commit method.
fields.summary: Diffs associated with a patch file get anchored to the wrong branch

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, if a user closes a review, re-opens it, and then closes it again, the REST APis for Crucible return the first close date only, and not the most recent. The GUI for Crucible displays the correct (most recent) close date.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a review. (In this example I'll refer to it at CR-1.)
# Close CR-1. Note the close time. (i.e. 17:08)
# Re-open CR-1.
# Close CR-1. Note that it does update the time of closure. (i.e. 17:10)
# Run a rest API call to http://<fisheyeURL>/rest-service/reviews-v1/CR-1/details
# Note that the returned closure date is the first close date. i.e: 
{noformat}<closeDate>2014-09-10T17:08:13.533+0200</closeDate>{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
The REST API should return the latest close date.

h3. Actual Results
The REST API returns the first close date.

h3.Workaround
There is no workaround at this time.
fields.summary: Crucible REST API Returns Incorrect Close Date

fields.description:
*Given*
User A and B, Review R.
A is the author,
B is the reviewer

*When*
B complete the review.
A refresh the review by adding new content

*Expecting*
The button of "uncomplete" will become "complete" on the review header after B reload R.
At the same time, the action dialog should also have an action call complete instead of uncomplete.

*Actual*
the action dialog does not refresh "uncomplete" to "complete".
fields.summary: The action dialog doesn't reload the actions when the review author reload the review

fields.description:
Due to this bug https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6114 , CLI tool in Crucible "crucible.py" will have the following error when uploading SVN diff with property changes:
{noformat}
$ python crucible.py 
Crucible server: http://localhost:8060
Crucible username: admin
Detected Crucible repository subversion. Use --repository or --noanchor options to override
Please specify a project to create the review in or an existing review id to add to [CR]: CR-1
Server Error: com.cenqua.crucible.revision.diff.patchDiff.PatchException: Unrecognised diff format. Expected diff hunk descriptor but found: 
{noformat}

It should provide a clear message that the "svn diff" has a property changes and it couldn't be added to the Crucible review. We will need to run the command "svn diff" and remove the property changes before uploading the patch file to Crucible Review manually.

The CLI tool "crucible.py" should also detect what is the SVN version installed in the machine. If it is SVN 1.8.x, "crucible.py" should use the option "--patch-compatible" for "svn diff" when generating the patch to be uploaded.
fields.summary: CLI should have a better error message for svn diff with property changes and use the option "--patch-compatible" if SVN 1.8.x is detected

fields.description:
*Attention*
Please notice the [Smart Commits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Using+smart+commits] documentation informs the issue key must be used in uppercase letters.

When a commit contains a JIRA issue key in its comment and the commit is added to a review, Crucible suggests to link the review to the JIRA issue mentioned in the comment.
If the issue key is in lower case, the creation of the link will fail, with the following message:
{noformat}
JIRA Server JIRA-6.2.7: This issue does not exist or you don't have permission to view it. Go to 'JIRA-6.2.7' or see your administrator.
{noformat}

*Resolution*
Despite the recommendation of the document first mentioned, it was checked this works in the most recent version of Crucible.
fields.summary: "Create Link" to JIRA issue fails if commit message contains key in lower case

fields.description:

The changeset is correctly added to the review but *the reviewer did not receive any emails*.

If the changeset have been added manually, the email would have been correctly delivered.

fields.description:
Currently the "Review Coverage" report for a repository gives details of the amount of code that has been subject to a code review for all commits to a repository.

However, this has two drawbacks:
1. It's not possible to exclude certain committers from the report - we have build server user which creates new branches in the repository when we do an automated release. It would be good to be able to exclude this user from the report.
2. It's not possible to focus just on one branch, so if we have different feature branches working concurrently, there's no way to see the % code review coverage for an individual branch.

The filters should allow for excluding / including particular users, and excluding / including particular branches, and when set they should affect the whole view (eg. the % of code coverage, the graph, etc.)
fields.summary: Allow filters in the "Review Coverage" report, include/exclude users, branches

fields.description:
I have created a review using mercurial patch files.  The author uploads a patch file which I review and comment on.  The author then creates a new patch file which only addresses my comments and is based off of the originally uploaded patch file (i.e. its parent is the node id of the original patch file).  Currently Crucible states that it is unable to anchor the patch file.

I believe that Crucible should be able to anchor the second (or any subsequent) patch file to a previously attached patch file.
fields.summary: Allow Pre-Commit Patches To Be Anchored To Previously Uploaded Patches

fields.description:
Typically the sequence of events is as follows: 

* While reviewing start to type a comment. 
* Before saving switch the view (full context/20 lines etc)
* This causes the comment to be saved as a draft. 
* Then click the edit button of the draft and finish the comment
* Now the problem occurs: can't get crucible to store the result. Neither pushing the "Comment" or "Keep as Draft" button seems to have any effect. You are able to switch files to look at or even navigate to the global comments section - the editable text box just won't go away anymore.

fields.description:
*When*
The user is on a review page and click on the objectives for the first time.

*Expected*
The page should scroll to the objectives and highlight the section 

*Actual*
The page did scroll, but the objectives first jump to the top of the page and then jump back again to the middle of the page which is strange in UX.

Besides, if you scroll manually on the content, and try to click the sidebar link again, the scrollbar will scroll one line per click.

*Info*
This is due to the problem of how we handle the scrolling on the review overview. Previously, we don't have the stalking header and the link was handle natively by page link hash. This behaviour doesn't work well with the new scrolling.
fields.summary: Strange behaviour when clicking objectives on the sidebar on Review page

fields.description:
Crucible is open in a review on my Browser FF 30.0 Windows 7.
The state of the review "Reviewer - 100% complete".
A colleague updates the review by adding 4 files.
A pop-up appears to my screen telling me that I need to reload the review.
I click on the reload link.
The state is not updated.
I click on Details link, the state is not updated.
I click on F5, the state is updated to "Reviewer - 22% reviewed"

Moreover, when a review goes ahead, by reading the files, the Details link does not refresh the progress of the review, i need to refresh (F5) the page.
fields.summary: Reload function does not work on Crucible 3.4.5 on FF 30.0

fields.description:
When a review has outstanding unlogged time and the "Close" button is pressed, the log work section displays a Submit button with the amount of time to log to the associated Jira issue. If the button is clicked, the correct amount of time shows in Crucible but Jira shows hours instead of minutes. It appears that the link does not append the 'm' to the entry.

Using Crucible:
Version:3.5.0 Build:20140722091943

and Jira:
v6.1.3#6158-sha1:b5b5eab

I have attached screenshots to the issue.

*Steps to reproduce:*
# Integrate JIRA 6.1+ (earlier has not been tested yet) with FishEye 3.5.1
# Make sure the default time tracking unit in JIRA is set to 'hours'
# Submit time log from a linked Crucible review to the JIRA issue
# Notice that the time submitted regardless to the unit, will be hours

*Workaround*
Use the default units as minutes and make sure to specify all values that way. See: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+Time+Tracking].
fields.summary: Minutes entered as hours into Jira when closing review

fields.description: Attached images show how user see review comments from two slightly different angles.
fields.summary: Unread comments background is barely visible on poor quality LCD monitors

fields.description:
Project Links make with that, when a user creates a review for a commit from a JIRA issue, the Crucible project linked to the JIRA project is already selected in the popup that shows up for project choosing.
If a Project Link is not in place, the Crucible project selected by default is the last project used to create a review.
It could be nice to have a feature that goes maybe in the user profile that allows the user to choose in which project he would like to create a review when creating it from JIRA. The default could be set by creating a Project Link, but if the instance has, for example, hundreds of projects, it is much more practical to let the user decide how he wants to select the Crucible projects when creating the reviews.

For instance, the user could have three options, according to his preference:
* When creating a review from JIRA:
** The default project should be the one that has the repository in which the commit is contained as the default repository for that project.
** The default project should be the last project used.
** The default project should be the project <List of projects>

Please take the example above just as the main options I could think when creating this.
fields.summary: Create a way to define the default Crucible project in which review will be created from JIRA

fields.description:
````The title of the review used to be a hyperlink (similar to how JIRA key is also a hyperlink in JIRA), this functionality has now been removed.

Customer  feedback - 

 "...can't easily copy it and send it to someone in email or instant messaging. I'm aware that you can copy it from URL bar but usually there are additional arguments there like "#details" or "#CFR-123456" etc. It's not a huge problem, you can always remove those additional stuff, but it's the details that matters when it comes to user experience."
fields.summary: Make Review Keys Hyperlinks again

fields.description:
The 'utf8' encoding in MySQL actually only supports utf8 code points between one and 3 bytes.  This means that several excellent and popular symbols, such as 👓,😦, and 🚜 cannot be used. MySQL 5.5 introduced *utf8mb4* character set. Note that is a utf8mb4 superset of utf8 so migrating shouldn't lose anything.

Tasks:

1. Work out a migration plan to automatically migrate Crucible instances to the utf8mb4 encoding which supports full unicode set. Note it's not just 'ALTER TABLE' but also 'ALTER DATABASE'.

2. Update com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.DBType.MYSQL#isUTF8AndCaseSensitive - we shall probably check 'utf8'/'utf8mb4' character encoding plus 'utf8_bin/utf8mb4_col' collation.

References:

* http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/charset-unicode-utf8mb4.html
* http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mapping_of_Unicode_character_planes#Basic_Multilingual_Plane
* http://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4 - useful list of steps required for migration
fields.summary: Determine a migration plan to migrate users on MySQL from utf8 to utf8mb4

fields.description:
Currently (in 3.5.0) there is no way with hot keys to walk over hidden comments. It will be very useful if "[" and "]" could walk over hidden comments. Or another keys.

The problem is that you cannot close the review if there are unread comments and it is hard to find those comments hidden around revisions. It is even harder if a file has a lot of revisions.
fields.summary: Hotkeys for walking on hidden comments

fields.description:
If a JIRA issue was just linked to the Review (from Review's *Edit Details*), I need to refresh the page before I can create a sub-task to that issue from a comment. 

*Steps to Reproduce*:
# Create a review in Crucible, adding some content to it.
# Click in *Edit Details*, link the review to a JIRA issue and click in *Done*.
# Click in the content added to see its source. 
# Add a comment to any line.
# From the comment click in *Create Issue*. The Sub-Task is not listed under the *JIRA Issue Type*

*Workaround*
# Refresh the page.
# Click in *Create Issue* from the comment. The Sub-Task is now listed.
fields.summary: Needs to refresh the page to create, from review comment, a sub-task of a recently linked issue

fields.description:
"Add Content to review dialog" to sort commits by Committer's date. 
That way it will be much easier to work with cherry-picked commits (picked from different moments in time). Currently the sorting is over Author's dates.
fields.summary: "Add Content to review" dialog to sort commits by Committer's date.

fields.description:
https://domain/rest-service/users-v1/some_username/ GET resource doesn't give e-mail information if you're logged in as a normal user (non-admin). But the strange thing is that if you try to see that user from normal Web interface it is possible to see its e-mail via this page:
https://domain/user/some_username
in About section. So there is some security misconception. If I see the e-mail on the web interface with certain user I should see it via Restful API, too.
fields.summary: Rest API doesn't show e-mail on users

fields.description:
When adding a new comment, the comment box will show the previous comment if the previous comment was created while in preview mode.

h5. Steps to reproduce
# Create a new code review and add a file.
# Click in the file to add a comment.
# Type some random text.
# *Click the Preview Comment button to preview the formatted comment.*
# Click the Comment button to accept the comment while in preview mode.
# Click on another line in the file to create a new comment.

At this point, the comment box will be in preview mode and will show the previously added comment. Clicking the Preview Comment button will return to an empty box.

h5. Expected behavior
Creating the second comment will show an empty comment box in edit mode, not preview mode.
fields.summary: Comment preview not cleared when adding new comments.

fields.description:
The suggestion is to be able to create separate groups with users only to be added to reviews. The idea is that these groups wouldn't be listed with the other user groups, neither managed by an external source; they would serve only to be added to reviews.

Similar to mail groups in a mail client. The list could be attached to a project or even under a user profile and shared with other users.
fields.summary: Ability to create "Reviewer teams"

fields.description: The Crucible Classifications need to be unique per project. However it appears the Crucible can customize the drop downs for defect (rank, Classification, custom, etc...) but it is bound to the entire project set in crucible. This needs to be scheme based like JIRA has so that you can map different drop down sets (classifications) to different projects.
fields.summary: Crucible Classifications unique by Project

fields.description:
Scenario:
 * review in project A (e.g. A-1) is moved to project B (B-1)
 * then it is moved back to project A and is assigned new id (A-2)
now customer may load review from any of the URLs: /cru/A-1, /cru/A-2, /cru/B-1 but random review id would be presented from the current project (i.e. A-1 or A-2).
fields.summary: random permid presented if review lived in same project few times

fields.summary: NullPointerException in reviews on deleted binary files, if there was property only change before deletion

fields.description:
1. Jump to the side because the gutter columns showing line number, author and changeset id expand. This occurs on Safari and Chrome, but not on Firefox. This occurs on 3.4.6-SNAPSHOT and 3.5.0-SNAPSHOT

(This is not regression but it would be great to fix)
*Given*
User $A is on review $r1
$r1 has frx $f1
$f1 has no comment

*When*
$A is viewing $f1
$A click on any line to make a comment, the comment form shows

*Expect*
The widths of columns of the code should stay the same.

*Actual*
Some columns seem to expand and some seem to shrink, which make the UI jumpy.

*Info*
This should be related to the table layout of the review page. And the comment/comment form is actually a table cell with a colspan of X which force the browser to recalculate the widths of columns.
fields.summary: Crucible expand the author/line number column width when inline comment is adding/added

fields.description: When adding a large number of changesets to a review, it can be tedious to click on each individual changeset. It would be nice to have the ability to bulk add a group of changesets or all changesets that have not been reviewed.
fields.summary: Option to bulk add changesets to a review

fields.description: Problem affects only source, changeset and review page.
fields.summary: Header is wrapping for very narrow pages

fields.description:
h1. Crucible
h2. Git
h3. Information
In FishEye, the Repository sidebar info display does not display the date of *Last Commit* for git repositories.

When associated with a repository, the Project sidebar info displays "31 Dec 69":
!2014-07-08_1811.png|thumbnail!

h3. HTR
Associate a git FishEye repository with a Crucible project via "FishEye Project Content" (Administration > Projects and select "Edit" under the column "FishEye Content").

h3. Current output
Synthetic date of "31 Dec 69"

h3. Expected output
Actual date of last commit.

h1. FishEye
h2. SVN

h3. Information
"Last Commit" date statistic is also incorrect for SVN repositories. 

SVN repo details:
- One physical repository.
- Many logical repositories.
- SVN structure is the default (trunk/, branches/, tags/).
- "Use Built-in Symbolic Rules" is selected -- no other rules are in place. 
- No Exclude/Include paths defined.
- No Start Revision defined.

!2015-05-15_1019.png|thumbnail!

h3. Current output 
The date displayed is "24 Feb"

h3. Expected output 
"14 May" per "trunk" not "root"
fields.summary: Stats "Last Commit" field shows incorrect date (FishEye + Crucible)
